raw_text:
Bank opts to leave rates on hold
 
 The Bank of England has left interest rates on hold at 4.75% for a sixth month in a row.
 
 The Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to take no action amid mixed signals from the economy. But some economists predict a further rise in the cost of borrowing will come later this year. Interest rates rose five times between November 2003 and August 2004 as soaring house prices and buoyant consumer data sparked inflation fears. Bank of England governor Mervyn King has recently warned against placing too much weight on one month's economic data, suggesting the MPC is waiting for a clearer picture to emerge. Economists see next week's inflation report from the MPC as key in assessing whether a further interest rate rise is necessary to keep the economy in check.
 
 Slower consumer spending and a quieter housing market are likely to have convinced the MPC that rates should be left unchanged in recent months. Inflation, however, has been rising faster than expected, hitting an annual rate of 1.6% in December - its highest level in six months. Data on Wednesday also showed manufacturing output rose at its fastest rate since May last month, reinforcing a view that economic growth was stronger than forecasts.
 
 And recent house surveys from the Halifax and Nationwide have indicated prices are still rising, albeit at a slower pace than in recent years. Philip Shaw, chief economist at Investec Securities, said he believed rates would remain at 4.75% for the rest of the year although strong economic data could lead to a further hike. "The economic landscape has changed quite considerably over the last couple of months, " he said. "Growth appears stronger and the MPC may become more concerned about inflation trends." Howard Archer, economist at Global Insight said the MPC "may well consider that the balance of risks to the growth and inflation outlook have moved from the downside to the upside".
 
 Business groups welcomed the MPC's widely-expected move to leave rates on hold and cautioned against further rises. The British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) said it was "concerned by the clamour in some quarters" for early interest rate increases. "We believe that these demands should be firmly resisted," said David Frost, BCC director general. "Manufacturing still faces extremely serious problems and is performing poorly, in spite of the recent revised figures." Ian McCafferty, chief economist at the CBI, said the MPC faced an "interesting" challenge. "Consumers appear to have pulled in their horns over the holiday period, and exporters are struggling with the strength of sterling," he said. "However, the broader economy continues to show healthy growth, and the tight labour market and buoyant commodity prices are nudging inflation higher."
llama3.2:1b: The Bank of England has left interest rates on hold at 4.75% for a sixth month.
The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided not to take action amid mixed signals from the economy.
Interest rates rose five times between November 2003 and August 2004 due to rising house prices and inflation fears, but economists predict a further rise will come later this year.
Despite slower consumer spending and a quieter housing market, inflation is rising faster than expected at an annual rate of 1.6% in December.
Strong economic growth and manufacturing output are also contributing to the increased inflationary pressures.

Economists predict a possible further rise in interest rates later this year, driven by inflation trends and strengthening economic growth.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Bank of England left interest rates on hold at 4.75% for six months in a row, despite mixed economic signals.
The MPC, led by Mervyn King, decided to leave rate changes unchanged amid concerns not all will be clear.
Economists predict further rate hikes this year due to rising inflation expectations.
Data showed slower spending and weaker housing markets, while manufacturing output improved faster than expected, but challenges remain about growth and inflation trends.
tinyllama:1.1b: Following a series of mixed signals in economic data, the Bank of England has left interest rates on hold at 4.75% for a sixth month in a row.
The Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to take no action amid signs that inflation is rising at an unprecedented pace.
However, economists suggest that a further rise in the cost of borrowing is due later this year as household spending continues to slow and a quiet housing market may weigh on consumer sentiment.
Inflection in recent house survey data has also raised concerns that economic growth may have weakened since last year.

However, business groups remain optimistic for interest rate increases, with the British Chamber of Commerce (BCC) expressing concern about early inflation rises, while CBI chief economist Ian McCafferty noted an "interesting" challenge for the Bank's policymakers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Bank of England has left interest rates on hold for a sixth consecutive month in response to concerns about rising house prices and the impact of economic conditions.
The MPC announced it would not make any further changes to its main lending rate until further indications emerge.
This decision comes after a period of stability, as the economy had been relatively strong with little evidence of inflationary pressures or excessive growth in consumer spending.
However, concerns about housing market activity have raised concerns over whether rising prices might be causing problems for consumers and businesses alike.
Analysts expect inflation to remain at a relatively high level in the coming months, as economists believe house price increases will slow down more quickly than previously anticipated.
This could lead to the Bank of England remaining on hold until further indications indicate that an increase in interest rates would not disrupt economic growth and inflation trends.
phi:2.7b: The Bank of England left interest rates at 4.75% for a sixth month in a row due to mixed economic signals.

Although economists predict a further rise in borrowing costs later this year, the MPC decided against it as slower spending and a quieter housing market convinced them that rates should remain unchanged.
However, inflation has been rising faster than expected.
House price surveys indicate prices are still on the up, but growth is slower than previous years.
The BCC and CBI both welcomed the decision to leave rates on hold but noted concerns about the economy's performance.
The MPC faced an "interesting" challenge in balancing economic growth and inflation.
orca-mini:3b: The Bank of England has decided not to raise interest rates due to conflicting signals from the economy.
However, some economists predict a further increase in borrowing costs later this year.
Interest rates have risen five times since November 2003 and August 2004 due to soaring house prices and consumer data sparking inflation fears.
The MPC is waiting for a clearer picture to emerge before making any decisions.
hermes3:3b: Bank of England keeps interest rates at 4.75% for sixth month, despite rising inflation and mixed economic signals.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Bank of England has maintained interest rates at 4.75% for a sixth month in a row, choosing not to take any action amidst mixed signals from the economy.

Some economists predict that there will be a further rise in borrowing costs later this year; however, slower consumer spending and a quieter housing market may have influenced the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) to leave rates unchanged.
While inflation has been rising faster than expected, recent data showed stronger economic growth than forecasts.
Business groups welcomed the decision not to increase interest rates but cautioned against further hikes, as some parts of the economy struggle.
The MPC will likely monitor the situation closely and reassess later in the year.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Bank of England has kept interest rates at 4.75% for the sixth consecutive month amid mixed economic signals.
While previous rate hikes were driven by inflation concerns from rising house prices and strong consumer data, the Bank is now waiting for a clearer economic picture.
Slower consumer spending and a cooling housing market influenced the decision, though inflation has risen to 1.6%, its highest in six months.
Strong manufacturing output and continued, albeit slower, house price growth suggest economic strength, leading some economists to predict a future rate hike.
Business groups welcomed the decision to hold rates steady and warned against further increases, citing challenges in manufacturing and exports.
The MPC will assess upcoming inflation data to determine future policy moves.

The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided against taking action due to recent economic data, but some economists predict further rate increases will occur later this year.
Inflation has been rising faster than expected, hitting an annual rate of 1.6% in December at its highest level in six months.
Manufacturing output has risen at its fastest rate since May, reinforcing the view that economic growth is stronger than anticipated.

The BCC cautioned against further interest rate increases due to issues such..
as slow consumer spending and a quieter housing market.
Philip Shaw, chief economist at Investec Securities, believes rates will remain at 4.0% for the rest of the year but may increase if strong economic data emerges.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) has decided to maintain interest rates at 4.75% for a sixth consecutive month, citing mixed economic signals.
While the housing market and consumer spending have slowed, inflation has accelerated to 1.6%, its highest rate in six months.
Economists predict further rate increases may occur later this year due to rising inflation and stronger economic data.
Business groups warn against premature interest rate hikes, emphasizing the UK manufacturing sector's poor performance.
The MPC must balance potential inflation threats with the economy's robust growth and tight labor market conditions.
